abstract.text: PHENIX results on jet modification with π 0 -and photon-triggered two particle correlations in p+p, p(d)+Au, and Au+Au collisions J.D. Osborn for the PHENIX Collaboration

body_text.text: Introduction
Two particle correlations are a powerful tool to probe a variety of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) interactions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In particular, correlations can provide information about the 2 → 2 hard partonic process in a given event.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: At the PHENIX experiment, high p T correlations are generally measured with a leading π 0 or direct photon.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Dihadron correlations have the benefit of being a high statistics measurement; additionally, the leading π 0 and away-side hadrons may both encounter strong force interactions leading to larger modifications.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Nonetheless, direct photon correlations are particularly sought after due to the photon emerging directly from the hard scattering; therefore, they provide the most precise measure of the initial partonic hard scattering kinematics in hadronic collisions where final-state hadrons are measured.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Photons additionally do not interact strongly, and thus are insensitive to QCD effects such as color exchanges or medium interactions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Therefore, the direct photon provides an excellent benchmark to understand these interactions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The PHENIX collaboration has recently measured high p T two-particle angular correlations in a variety of collision systems.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Direct photon-hadron correlations have been measured in d+Au and Au+Au collisions, while π 0 -hadron correlations have been measured in p+Al and p+Au collisions at √ s NN = 200 GeV.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Both π 0 -hadron and direct photon-hadron correlations have also been measured in p+p collisions at √ s = 200 and 510 GeV.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The PHENIX detector is capable of measuring these correlations in azimuth, Δφ = φ trig − φ assoc , utilizing its central arm electromagnetic calorimeters to measure trigger photons or neutral pions and tracking system, composed of drift and pad chambers, to measure associated hadrons.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The central arms cover an azimuthal acceptance of approximately π radians and a pseudorapidity acceptance of |η| < 0.35.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Studying effects from color flow in p+ p collisions
In the last several decades, there has been strong interest in the multi-dimensional structure of the proton [1].
body_text.section: Studying effects from color flow in p+ p collisions

body_text.text: In particular, this interest has led to new predictions that are specific to non-Abelian gauge invariant quantum field theories.
body_text.section: Studying effects from color flow in p+ p collisions

body_text.text: For example, in a transverse-momentum-dependent (TMD) framework, where the nonperturbative transverse momentum of partons within a hadron are explicitly considered, QCD factorization breaking has been predicted in the process p+p → h 1 +h 2 +X [2].
body_text.section: Studying effects from color flow in p+ p collisions

body_text.text: In hadronic collisions, where at least one final-state hadron is measured and a TMD framework is applicable, soft gluons may be exchanged in both the initial and final states.
body_text.section: Studying effects from color flow in p+ p collisions

body_text.text: This leads to complex color flows that correlate the partons and result in the breakdown of TMD factorization.
body_text.section: Studying effects from color flow in p+ p collisions

body_text.text: To study these predicted effects, PHENIX has measured the p out = p assoc
body_text.section: Studying effects from color flow in p+ p collisions

body_text.text: . Constructing the correlations in a fixed bin of x E allows for a better comparison between bins of p trig T since x E is a proxy for the away-side longitudinal momentum fraction z. The measured p out distributions are shown in the left panel of Fig. 1, where the open (filled) markers are the π 0 -hadron (direct photon-hadron) correlations and each marker color shows a different p trig T bin. The distributions show a two component shape, which is characterized by a Gaussian fit at small p out and a power law-like tail from the Gaussian at large p out . The two shapes arise due to sensitivity to soft gluon radiation in the |p out | ∼ 0 region and hard gluon radiation in the |p out | 0 region, indicating the applicability of a TMD framework since there is sensitivity to both a hard and soft transverse momentum scale. The Gaussian widths, shown in the right panel of Fig. 1, increase as a function of p trig T , which is qualitatively consistent with nonperturbative momentum width measurements in the Drell-Yan process where factorization is predicted to hold (see e.g. [4]). Future quantitative phenomenological comparisons will be necessary which compare these different processes to understand the quantitative magnitude of TMD factorization breaking effects.
body_text.section: Studying effects from color flow in p+ p collisions

body_text.text: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A
In proton-nucleus collisions, dihadron correlations can be used to search for QCD interactions with the nucleus.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: In this case, the near-side triggered π 0 is more likely to emerge near the surface of the nucleus and thus the away-side hadron may on average experience a larger path length than in direct photon-hadron correlations; therefore, when searching for nuclear effects, dihadron correlations may be more sensitive to modification than direct photon-hadron correlations.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: PHENIX has measured the p out distributions on the away-side and near-side in p+p, p+Al, and p+Au collisions.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: Similarly to the previous p+p results, the Gaussian widths are extracted from each collision species, and the squared width differences are determined to search for transverse momentum broadening in p+A collisions.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: The squared Gaussian width differences between p+A and p+p are shown in the left panel of Fig. 2 as a function of x E .
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: The top (bottom) row shows the width differences between p+Al and p+p (p+Au and p+p), while the left (right) column shows the near-side (away-side) width differences.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: The left column shows that, within the current uncertainties, there is no difference between the near-side nonperturbative widths in p+Al(Au) and p+p for the x E range measured.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: The lack of near-side transverse momentum broadening suggests that final-state fragmentation differences in p+p and p+A collisions are small.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: In the right column, there is a nonzero and statistically significant nonperturbative momentum width difference between p+Au and p+p; a small difference can be seen in the away-side width differences between p+Al and p+p, however the uncertainties are consistent with no difference.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: To study this nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening as a function of collision system size, the two x E bins where a nonzero difference can be seen are shown as a function of N coll in the right panel of Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: The broadening is a function of N coll , indicated by the linear fits to each x E bin.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: This dependence may set tight constraints on energy loss within a nucleus; however, the broadening may also be explained by potential additional initial-state partonic transverse momentum in a nucleus or multiple scattering effects.
body_text.section: Nonperturbative transverse momentum broadening in p+A

body_text.text: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au
Since direct photons are expected to be produced with little activity in the near vicinity, isolation cuts are often used to boost their signal-to-background from decay photon processes.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: The implementation of these cuts is common in p+p and p(d)+Au collisions; however, their use in Au+Au collisions can be challenging due to the larger underlying-event backgrounds.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: PHENIX has, for the first time at RHIC, measured isolated direct photon-hadron correlations in Au+Au collisions using a modified statistical subtraction method similarly to what is used in p+p collisions.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: The isolation cut increases the statistical significance of the direct photon yields in Au+Au collisions and and allows a more precise study of the z T = p assoc T /p trig T dependence of away-side hadron suppression and enhancement.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: In these new results, direct photons and associated hadrons are collected in the range 5 < p trig T < 15 GeV/c and 1 < p assoc T < 10 GeV/c, respectively.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: The low and high z T away-side hadron I AA = Y AA /Y pp , where Y AA is the integrated away-side yield in Au+Au or p+p collisions as indicated, as a function of centrality is shown in the left panel of Fig. 3 for isolated direct photon-hadron correlations.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: The I AA values show the characteristic suppression at high z T , in red, and enhancement relative to suppression at low z T , in blue, indicative of quark gluon plasma formation.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: The larger accumulated data sample and isolation cut implementation allow for a more robust characterization compared to the previous PHENIX publication [5] of this enhancement to suppression ratio, shown in the bottom of the left panel.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: In particular, this ratio shows a clear monotonic increase as a function of centrality, which is now more precisely identified.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: The high z T suppression is also shown compared to the inclusive π 0 R AA in the right panel of Fig. 3.
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: The isolation cone implementation significantly improves the uncertainties from the previous publication [6].
body_text.section: Isolation cut method for direct photons in Au+Au

body_text.text: Summary
The PHENIX collaboration has measured direct photon-hadron and dihadron correlations in p+p, p+Al, p+Au, and Au+Au collisions at √ s NN = 200 GeV.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: In p+p collisions, processes predicted to be sensitive to color flow in a TMD framework are studied and found to be qualitatively similar to Drell-Yan measurements, indicating the need for detailed theoretical calculations in processes predicted to break factorization.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: In p+A collisions, away-side transverse momentum broadening has been measured and this broadening appears to be dependent on N coll , potentially setting constraints on energy loss in a nucleus.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: In Au+Au collisions, an isolation cut has significantly improved the systematic uncertainties on direct photon-hadron correlations and thus the study of high and low associated hadron z T suppression and enhancement, respectively, and thus energy redistribution in Au+Au events.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The analysis of the additional recent high statistics Au+Au data sets from PHENIX will continue to provide important constraints to our understanding of QCD.
body_text.section: Summary
